questions.question: What does CRM stand for, and why is it a terrible name for what VC funds need?

options.text: Customer Relationship Management - but VCs don't have customers, they track relationships with founders and manage deal pipeline
Company Resource Management - but it's not about resources
Capital Relationship Management - but it's not about capital

questions.explanation: CRM stands for Customer Relationship Management, which is a terrible name for what venture funds need. You're not managing customers. You're tracking relationships with founders, managing deal pipeline, coordinating your team, and maintaining institutional memory about every company you've ever talked to.

questions.question: Why do CRMs feel terrible to use for VC funds?

options.text: Because they're built for sales organizations with standardized stages, but VC is messier - every deal is different and stages aren't linear
Because they don't have enough features

questions.explanation: CRMs feel terrible because they're built for sales organizations. Enterprise sales has standardized stages: lead, qualified, demo, proposal, negotiation, closed. Venture doesn't work this way - deals move forward, sideways, and sometimes back. The stages aren't linear. The timeline isn't predictable. CRMs force you to contort your process into their model.

questions.question: What are the core functions a CRM needs to support for VC funds? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Relationship tracking - every person you've met and the context of your relationship
Company tracking - every company you've evaluated
Deal pipeline - what deals are active and what stage they're at
Team coordination - who's talking to which founders

questions.explanation: A CRM needs to support: (1) Relationship tracking - every person you've met, how you met them, when you last talked, what you talked about. (2) Company tracking - every company you've evaluated and the full history of interactions. (3) Deal pipeline - what deals are active, who's working on them, what stage they're at. (4) Team coordination - preventing duplicate outreach and surfacing relevant context.

questions.question: Why should you model your CRM at the deal level rather than the company level?

options.text: Because deals are more important than companies
Because VCs invest in deals (specific funding rounds), not companies - you can't mark a company as both 'Invested' and 'Passed' at the same time

questions.explanation: VCs invest in deals (specific funding rounds), not companies. Model your CRM at the deal level: 'Acme Corp Seed Round' (Invested), 'Acme Corp Series A' (Invested), 'Acme Corp Series B' (Passed). If you model at the company level, you'll have problems when follow-on rounds come up - you can't mark a company as both 'Invested' and 'Passed' at the same time.

questions.question: What is the recommendation regarding building your own CRM?

options.text: Don't build your own CRM from scratch - buy something customizable like Attio or Affinity
Only build if you're a large fund

questions.explanation: Building your own CRM from scratch is worse than using an existing one. Buy something customizable, integrate it with your other tools, and commit to actually using it. Don't build it yourself.

questions.question: What are the main differences between Attio and Affinity?

options.text: Attio is more flexible and customizable, while Affinity is built specifically for VC with purpose-built workflows but less flexibility

questions.explanation: Attio is modern, flexible, and designed with relationship-centric businesses in mind. Better UX than traditional CRMs, strong customization without requiring a full-time admin. Affinity is built specifically for relationship-driven industries like venture capital, automatically enriches contact data, and has purpose-built VC workflows out of the box but less flexibility.

questions.question: Why shouldn't you start with Airtable or Notion for deal flow tracking?

options.text: Because they don't integrate well with email and calendar - you have to manually enter everything
Because they're only for large teams

questions.explanation: Don't start with Airtable or Notion. The problem is that they don't integrate well with email and calendar. You have to manually enter everything. What happens is that people stop updating it within weeks. You end up with a partially-filled database that nobody trusts or uses, and you've lost all the email and meeting history that a real CRM would have captured automatically.

questions.question: What is the single most important habit for making CRM work?

options.text: Using it in deal flow calls - updating company stages, adding notes, assigning next steps
Keeping it separate from other tools

questions.explanation: The single most important habit: Use it in deal flow calls. When your team discusses deal flow, have the CRM open. Update company stages. Add notes. Assign next steps. If you talk about a company and don't update the CRM, information gets lost. Make it part of the meeting process, not something you do afterward.

questions.question: Why is integrating CRM with email and calendar critical?

options.text: Because the less manual data entry, the more people will actually use it

questions.explanation: Integrate with your other tools. The CRM should connect to your email (Gmail, Outlook), calendar, and other tools. When you email a founder, it logs automatically. When you have a meeting, it logs automatically. The less manual data entry, the more people will actually use it.

questions.question: What is the key difference between VC deal flow and transactional sales workflows?

options.text: VC deal flow isn't linear - companies move forward, sideways, and sometimes back

questions.explanation: The key difference from transactional sales workflows: VC deal flow isn't linear. Companies move forward, sideways, and sometimes back. You might pass on a company's seed round and lead their Series A. A 'watchlist' company might sit dormant for two years then become your best investment.

questions.question: When should you consider Salesforce for CRM?

options.text: Only if you're large enough to have dedicated CRM admin resources

questions.explanation: Salesforce is the enterprise standard - extremely customizable with a massive ecosystem. The downsides are cost (expensive for small funds), complexity (requires real admin overhead), and UX that feels dated. Larger, established funds with dedicated operations teams sometimes use Salesforce because they need complex workflows and have resources to maintain it. Not recommended for small funds.

questions.question: What should you prioritize when setting up your CRM workflow?

options.text: Designing the perfect pipeline with many stages
Start simple - you can always add complexity later
Copy exactly what other funds do

questions.explanation: Don't overthink the workflow. Many funds spend weeks designing the perfect pipeline stages and custom fields. This is usually overengineering. Start simple. You can always add complexity later. The basics (who are we talking to, what stage are they at, what's the next step) cover 80% of what you need.

questions.question: Why is search and filtering important in a CRM?

options.text: Because if you can't find information quickly, you won't use the system

questions.explanation: Search and filtering are critical. Find all the AI infrastructure companies you talked to in the last year. Find everyone you met at that conference. Find all the founders you passed on who you said you'd check back with in six months. If you can't find information quickly, you won't use the system. Unfortunately, search systems on CRMs are inexplicably poor.

questions.question: What were the key distinctions in Inflection's deal funnel stages?

options.text: Watchlist (companies we might revisit) versus Passed (definitely not), and Lost (we wanted to but couldn't) versus Passed (we chose not to)
They used the same stages as sales

questions.explanation: Inflection's deal funnel included stages like New, Initial Contact, Research, Term Sheet, Invested, Watchlist, Passed, and Lost. The key distinctions are Watchlist (companies we might revisit) versus Passed (definitely not), and Lost (we wanted to but couldn't) versus Passed (we chose not to). These capture the non-linear nature of VC relationships better than a pure sales funnel.

questions.question: What is the hardest part of implementing a CRM?

options.text: The discipline of actually using it consistently

questions.explanation: The hardest part isn't choosing the right tool. It's the discipline of actually using it consistently. Use it in deal flow calls. Make sure email and meeting tracking work automatically. Keep the data current. A mediocre CRM used consistently is better than a perfect CRM that nobody updates.

questions.question: How can funds use CRM beyond deal flow management?

options.text: They can't - CRM is only for deal flow
Many funds also use their CRM to manage LP relationships - tracking interactions, managing fundraising pipelines, maintaining investor reporting history

questions.explanation: Beyond deal flow, many funds also use their CRM to manage LP relationships. Tracking interactions with current and potential LPs, managing fundraising pipelines, and maintaining investor reporting history. The same principles apply: relationship tracking, interaction history, and systematic follow-up. Some funds use separate systems for LPs, others use the same CRM with different pipelines.

questions.question: What should you do with CRM APIs?

options.text: Use them to build light integrations between your CRM and research platform, sourcing tools, and anything else you use
Only use them if you're technical

questions.explanation: Most CRMs have APIs. Use them. Build light integrations between your CRM and your research platform, your sourcing tools, and anything else you use. The CRM becomes more valuable when it's connected to the rest of your stack.

questions.question: What happens if you don't commit to entering data in your CRM?

options.text: The system becomes incomplete and people stop trusting it
It gets better on its own

questions.explanation: Commit to entering data. There's no way around this. Someone needs to enter information about companies, founders, and meetings. With good email and calendar integration, a lot happens automatically. But initial company setup, notes from meetings that aren't on calendar, and context about relationships still require manual entry. The key is making it low-friction.

questions.question: What should you prioritize when choosing a CRM?

options.text: The one with the most features
Prioritize customizability over features - you'll need to adapt the CRM to match your fund's specific process

questions.explanation: Prioritize customizability over features. You'll need to adapt the CRM to match your fund's specific process. Attio and Affinity are both good choices for most funds. Attio if you want more control over structure and workflow. Affinity if you want VC-specific features.

questions.question: What is the bottom line recommendation for CRM?

options.text: Buy a CRM (Attio or Affinity for most funds), customize it, integrate it, and commit to using it
Don't use a CRM at all

questions.explanation: Buy a CRM. Don't build one. Don't start with Airtable or Notion. Choose something designed for relationship management (Attio or Affinity for most funds), customize it to match your process, integrate it with your other tools, and commit to using it.
